												I really wanted to like this game -- the characters are fascinating, and it does have good gameplay.  But this is one of the most cynical MOBAs out there.  Take League of Legends, and cross it with some of the more obnoxious Facebook games.  Energy mechanics to play specific characters (although you can spend in-game cash to reset them), Farmville mechanics to gather resources necessary to get boosts.  Rather than League's runes, masteries, and normal 'Q/W/E/R' levelling, you set up 36 possible levels in their own Rune system -- but those runes have Gacha style randomness, different levels of rarity / effectiveness, and you can combine runes together to level them up to level 5.  These set up the level up bonuses that you get in match -- and their strength also contributes to the normal level up bonuses you get.At all steps you're given incentives to pay money -- money can get you double XP towards your characters to increase their stats in a small way, double your rune drops, turn off the green (common, and incredibly weak) drops entirely, and many other things.  While this game is ostensibly free to play...it's incredibly pay to win, as well.  A person who spends money can buy some legendary runes to start off with that are a good headstart, buy the ability to pick up runes more easily, and buy the ability to get their resources faster to level things up.The gameplay is fun...but I can't continue to play it with just how horrible the metagame is.  Add to this the fact that the game is mostly popular in Russia and other Asian countries, with no regional servers--so you will almost always be matched with 3 or 4 players that do not speak your language, and it's just not for me anymore.

												Positives:-The support that I've received has been very helpful. -The town / economy building section is pretty neat-Earning exp and gold (same thing) in game to spend on abilities or pots/truesight/scrolls is interesting, being rewarded with more "exp" for last hitting is neat.-Multiple game modes, including the standard 3 lane 5v5, a pve mode, and others that are rotated on a clock schedule-It can be a refreshing game change if you need a break from other more demanding mobas, like Dota or even League_____________________________________________Neutral:-Bought heroes. I have the opinion that, like LoL and every other game that does this, if you limit core mechanics with currency then it can never be a truly competitive game. Does LoL have competitions and is extremely popular and makes a lot of money? Yes, but McDonalds is extremely popular and makes a lot of money, but I wouldn't call that food.If you want something to be truly competitive and legitimate on a general playerbase level, you can't limit core mechanics to anyone.However, it adds incentive to grind and play, and some people prefer that.-Very simple. It may not seem that way at first with the flood of new information, but once you learn the Talent groups and get the gist of things it's a very simple game. Last hitting or being near creep deaths earns resource which you use to buy your abilities and stats, which levels you up._____________________________________________Negatives:-Matchmaking. As a newish player, though a moba veteran, I find myself going against people with max level heroes and full rare or epic talent sets, and even some unique ones, when I myself have new heroes with no bonus stats and standard or uncommon talents. This is akin to a level 1 League player with no runes or masteries fighting level 30 players. It doesn't matter your skill level, or even if you're better than they are, there's just a very heavy disadvantage stat wise from the start. This makes carrying any allies very hard, especially if they feed. Normally you would be able to overcome that, but not with the stat advantage in addition.-Language barrier. Over my hours on this game, I've run into one other person who wasn't a friend that spoke or understood English. This could be overcome by a translational chat wheel, or other similar device. One type of ping is not enough to communicate, especially when they're often spammed. As a side note, after playing this game you will actually be thankful for "that one guy" on your team in Dota or League who you thought was bad.I'm going to give this game more time and chances. At the very least, it's nice to go to when I don't want to exert myself on more complex mobas.Until they fix the matchmaking however, I can't recommend this game.

												A foreword about me: I played a lot of DotA back when it was called DotA 3.3 as a WarCraft 3 non-expansion custom map. I played succeeding versions up to 3.7, Danite's Hell, and those that supported game modes such as -aram. I've also been a progression and hardmore raider in WoW and SWTOR. I play League of Legends casually.Now about Prime World:This is a MOBA but it's not just a MOBA.It has the grind of an MMO that both casual and hardcore players can enjoy.Casuals might like the city-building and city-management aspects of the game. You build buildings and order them to produce wood, ore, food, silver, crystals, or gold (cash shop currency). These resources can be used to buy heroes (like LoL champions), buy hero skins, buy talents, upgrade buildings, upgrade talents, send heroes on quests at the tavern, or rest heroes at the inn (heroes need to rest after a match or quest).Casuals might also like the Zuma-type game in the actual MOBA part of the game. On the 5v5 map, you can have 3 laners, 1 jungler, and 1 playing Zuma, which helps your team maximize everybody's XP gain. When playing Zuma, a successful game rewards you with a one-time consumable scroll that you can send to anyone on your team, including yourself. The spell on the scroll, and the strength of the spell, is something you select before each Zuma game. For instance, you could start the 5v5 match and play Zuma to create a level 1 healing scroll for your jungler, or a level 5 AoE damage scroll for an early lane push.Finally, for casuals, there is also a PvE map, ranging from easy, medium, hard, to very hard difficulty. And by PvE, I don't mean a "vs AI" game, where you're still in an arena but fighting bot players. This map involves protecting a central location from waves of enemies. There are also side quests throughout the "match", such as escorting an NPC down a lane or defeating all of a specific type of enemy on the map. Hardcore players can enjoy the endgame, because there is quite a grind when you want to pwn with the best in the world. Your city can produce talents, but you are also rewarded talents when you play and especially when you win. Talent rarity is similar to WoW's, where some are junk and others are legendary, going from yellow, green, blue, purple, to orange. Each talent also has five ranks each, and you can, using WoW terms, disenchant all your junk talents in order to enchant your purples and oranges.Endgame players can also enjoy the theorycrafting that comes with the flexibility of talent and stat builds. Using LoL terms, some heroes can be built for AD or AP (like LoL's Ezreal or Tristana), and some benefit from both (Akali). Most talents give you passive stat upgrades (+7 agility or +2.2 health regeneration), but others give you a usable skill (temporary invulnerability or immobilize enemy or self heal). I have only three complaints about Prime World.1) Matchmaking can sometimes fail you horribly (or benefit you immensely), matching up lesser geared/experienced teams against epicced out players. Mind you, bad matchmaking does not always guarantee a loss for the underdog.2) Disconnects are an issue. On a good day, all my games go smoothly and everybody has good games. On a bad day, half my games turn into 5v4 or 5v3.3) My biggest complaint is that all players globally play on the same server, and most are Russian, which leads to ZERO communication. The best you can do is to know the game, know every class, have good map awareness, and hope that your team is as good as you are.Bottom line: I love this game now. I would say it's more casual than LoL, where people rage on you for being new and not executing your skillshots or timing your CCs perfectly. But then again, maybe they do rage here in Prime World and I just can't understand the Cyrillic alphabet. :)

Prime World - An outstanding MOBAHey guys,I've been playing Prime World for 2 months now or in other words ~500 hours of playing time. As I played League of Legends and DotA2 before I was wondering what another MOBA might bring to the table to make me stick with it.But I can tell you: There were things that did.First of all a short overview:+ Several unique Heros all with their own playstyle+ Different game modes+ Talent-System+ Nice graphics+ Castle-System+ Easy to learn+ Mostly polite and nice gamers around there- Low playerbase -> therfor sometimes real terrible matchmaking- Talent-System (yes it's also negative sometimes, more on that later)As you might know Prime World is another MOBA title. But there are two things that are making this one really unique. The Talent-System and the Castle-System.For the Castle-System: It is nothing spectacular and reminds me of some tycoon style games on facebook. You have your buildings to get some additional Income or Talents. Productions take from 30 Minutes up to 23 hours. But it's fun to organize and manage your castle during your Queue Times.The Talent-System is what makes the game unique to play. There is no exp or gold in the matches, only prime. With Prime you can unlock the heros talents which you organize and plan in the castle before even going to the battlefield. This offers you some tactical decision making aswell as the opportunity to play heros in really different ways. Also you can determinate if you want to specialize on something with your hero or be more like an allrounder.After every match you get some talents. Some of those are more common, some of those are really rare and therfor more powerful.For me it is really fun to play many matches and it's awesome to finally get a much desired Talent after many games. But I guess it can also be really frustrating, especially as the quality of your heros talents also determinates the power of your hero ingame. So if you're exactly on the same skill level like your opponent and even playing the same hero, but he is epic talented and you are only common you will lose. So it takes some time to get heros strong. If you like this talent farming, like me, it's awesome for sure, but if you just want a smooth start in the game without any disadvantages at start you should probably play DotA2 instead.What the game mostly suffers from is its low playerbase. The matchmaking really sucks often because there are just not enough players to make it work.Also when you start playing the game you get Tutorial Quests. One of them is winning 10 pvp games. You have a own Queue for people having this quest pending which would be nice if there just were some more of them. This way new players face terrible queue times (1h+) and most likely quit before even giving the game the chance it deserves for sure. You can get around this by looking for people in the world chat who already finished this quest and ask them to group with you. But this way you get much higher opponents which might not only be frustrating, but also tends to make reaching 10 wins a real pain in the ♥♥♥.Still I like this MOBA most of all those out there, as it is more about teamwork and tactical decision making than individual skill, like in League or DotA. Hopefully it will at some point get the love it deserves and the playerbase to run smooth. There is so much potential and it is definitely worth a try!

												First I thought this was a random MOBA type game, but it's not. Besides the usual regular map similar to other games, it brings several other modes, including an Outpost mode where you battle 3x3 on a one lane area, a native land arena, where your abilities are stronger depending on how much land your team owns, a dragon 4x4 fight where you battle mobs towards the middle, fight the dragon then get to fight the other team and a zombie arena where your enemies are turned to zombies allied with you when they die. As a major difference from regular MOBAs, the hero does not need to buy artifacts inside the fighting game, but they get time to arrange their talents before the battle in their town. After each battle you win some talents and you can progress your heroes using these talents creating an unique hero. The player can add abilities to their hero with these talents and alter the stats to their desire. Of course for newer players some suggested stats that a hero usually uses are highlighted so the player can have an idea of what talents they could try.Besides this hero fighting game, the game offers a base building mechanic. I shall admit that this isn't extremely polished and could use some work, but the idea is a good one. The base acts as a home for the heroes, where you can produce talents and train your heroes. The drawbacks of the game are the lower population playing it and the matchmaking sytem, which, because of lower population, sometimes ends putting players with huge differences of skill in opposite teams. Overall, the game is fun to play.Edit: I have found a major turn-off. Heroes are not well balanced against eachother. Some heroes are too strong from start. And because of the skewed matchmaking system, you may end up being matched with people who have both good heroes and some of the best artifacts, which will mean that you'll start losing the game from the start and it progresses it will only become easier for the enemies.

												I love this game, and hate it, but mostly love it. I love it because there is so much progression, you are leveling up stuff all the time. You have a castle and a Lord(you) that you level up, buildings in the castle you level, you have champs that you level up, and you level up their gear(called talents), and you can make/join a clan, and level that up. Gameplay is fun, and you have plenty PvE to do. You can do challenge maps for gear, and various bot games. So why hate it at all? PvP. You must understand that it is not balanced, and that doesn't mean it's bad. Right now the game is set to match you up based on your performance, based on wins. However, gear and character level play a huge role in balance. Gear is divided into levels, like World of Warcraft and other games, based on color and stats. Yellow gear, Green, Blue, Purple, Orange, and each piece has different active or passive abilities or stat increases, as well as the ability to boost your overall stats. Your character has a power rating based on gear score, so you may be in all yellow and green gear with a 1200 power score, and have to fight someone in rare and epic gear whose character level may also be higher, and sometimes, your entire team will be lower level and outgeared, even though your ranking may be similar. Each character level lets you put a couple skill points into your character, so you may face the same champ in lane as you, similarly geared, but if the level difference going in is significant, you are weaker. Skill can overcome that, but skill can't overcome both significant level and gear differences. Factor in that you will often have quitters and afkers, and at the moment no way to report them, and you could easily find yourself wanting to punch a hole in the wall.But if you know that is the way it is, and don't expect that just cause you are better skilled but may still lose...a lot, then you will have fun, imo.

Another thing about the game that is better than LoL is that you can collect plenty of silver rather fast so that you can purchse the higher level chrs. 												Interesting. There are so many things in one game. However, I think Prime World Thrones tries to be too many things at once and doesn't integrate it together. I believe they just found a whole bunch of concepts from click-farming, MOBA, MMORPG and city building and just mashed it all up into PW:T. It's horrible.PROS1. Fun StuffThere are mini-games that resembe Zuma, a bubble popping game that has you shooting bubbles to makes combine 3 of a colour on a snake-like trail.2. Defense maps / ChallengesHordes of monsters just keep pouring on and you have got to kill them all.3. Easy unlocking of heroesThere are quests you can do in the other mini-games that unlock the heroes. As long as you reach level 36 and have enough silver, you should be able to get all the heroes. However, locking the core mechanic of the game away from players is mostly stupidity on the developer's end.CONS1. Doesn't gelAll the mini-games do not gel. How could you have a Zuma game in the middle of a MOBA battle just to produce a scroll? That will mean 1 afk player aiming to build a specific scroll.2. Pay-to-WinYou actually have to rest your hero so that you can use him. His Vigour needs to be restored at a Spa. Not only that, they make you buy things called Talents to upgrade your hero with gold (cash currency). Talents are special skills that you get in-game when you level up during MOBA combat, a wrong combination will make you very weak or very strong.3. City BuilderThis begun to get pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ once I started seeing a need to click-farm and build a city. You have to play multiple games in that don't make sense. You build a city to produce housing, food, silver, thread, Prime and a spa. What are they trying to do with this?4. Hero UpgradingThere are Mastery points, which are stat points, and Talents that severely imbalance a game. If you play the game till max level and you get enough Master points, your hero's stats will be far superior to another player's. If you get super rare and powerful Talents that you equip on your hero, you will also be imbalanced.5. Hero ListsMirror Image. 												Summary:At first glance, Prime World appears an ambitious MOBA that tries to take the genre to the next level.  While I don't think it necessary does that, if you're a fan of the genre, this game would be worth a look, at the very least... if the community wasn't trash.---------------Pros:Exp and currency are tied together into something called "prime".  You spend prime to level up, buy potions, buy scrolls, etc.The native terrain element rewards smart, tactical play with some nice bonuses.The zuma element is an interesting "second jungle" with team-wide benefits, adding additional laning and support possibilities in the early game.Starter heroes are completely viable against more expensive heroes, as long as you know how to use them.PvE "Challenge" maps allow for a more relaxed atmosphere to learn how a class works, before you jump into the fire.The cash shop is strictly a pay to advance faster system, as opposed to a pay to win system.  You don't need to spend a dime on the game to be considered good at the game.---------------Cons:The tutorial system assumes that you're capable of learning a lot of stuff on your own.  All it really teaches you to do is how to play the laning phase and how to ultimately win the match.Talent farming.  In a nutshell, the more you play, the more likely you are to get good talents, which are effectively where your power comes from.  The grind element can be a bit tedious early on, when you're still trying to gear up, leading to some matches where you're just going to be out-scaled no matter what you do.A horrible newbie matchmaking system causes long queues when trying to obtain your first ten wins, with leavers, bots, ragers, etc flooding that entire queue.  The devs have stated that the issue stems from a lack of people in that queue, and changes are coming to fix it.  In the meantime, it's still a horrible queue.  The game gets a lot better after those first ten wins, in which you'll escape that queue, but those first few matches do turn a lot of people away from the game.No counterbuilds on the fly.  What you load into your profile before the match is what you get, no matter how good or bad it is against the other team's composition.  Some pro players may not like this.The castle system.  I'm not a big fan of it.  The whole point of it appears to be to fuel your ability to obtain new heroes, obtain new talents, and help your heroes recover.  It seems like a restrictive system designed to make you want to drop some cash on the game.A horrible community that punishes people for "doing it right".  If you're not suicide rushing into a 2v4 situation to save a feeder, you're doing it wrong, according to this community.  And you're going to be seeing this happen.  Every.  Single.  Match.  No avoiding it.---------------Do I recommend this game?Not just no, but heck no.  If this small community comprehended proper MOBA mechanics, it's a nice niche game.  But it's just full of people who don't comprehend the genre, coupled with an incredibly small community, making for long wait times.  The game is decent, but the community just makes it unbearable.  Stay away if you value your sanity.
